thread.title: Australia, NZ told to partner up on innovation
thread.title_full: Australia, NZ told to partner up on innovation | Business Spectator

author: Supratim Adhikari
title: Australia, NZ told to partner up on innovation
text:
Peak internet body Internet Australia has called for the formation of a trans-Tasman regional innovation zone, where Australia and New Zealand explore the challenges and opportunities of a digitally enabled world economy.
The proposal has been put forward by internet Australia’s CEO, Laurie Patton, in a keynote address at the Australia and New Zealand internet Awards (ANZIAs) in Auckland last night, who added that an arrangement would be a natural extension of the existing ‘Closer Economic Relations’ agreement.
According to Mr Patton, forging a regional initiative might go a long way in preventing local talent from dispersing to other parts of the globe.
“The first thing we need to do is to stop our ‘best and brightest’ heading off to Silicon Valley, or to other places in the world where innovation is more highly valued, or better facilitated”, Mr Patton said.
“We need to create an environment where failure is not the end of the road; where determination to succeed is recognised and applauded; and where funding is available at all stages of the innovation curve.”
He also added that while there was an understandable focus on the economic rewards expected to flow from digital innovation, there was ample opportunity to deliver positive social outcomes.
This article was first published in The Australian Business Review.
